properties.Title: Tropical Storm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Tropical storm force winds associated with Post-Tropical Storm Teddy are expected over the regions, but will remain just below wind warning criteria. Potential wind gusts: 65 to 80 km/h over exposed areas and along parts of the coast. Locations: The Annapolis Valley, northern Nova Scotia, and western Cape Breton. Time span: continuing into this afternoon. Remarks: Strong northwesterly winds are expected in the wake of Teddy as it crosses eastern Nova Scotia in the morning. These northwesterly winds could potentially gust to 70 to 80 km/h as well before diminishing late in the day. ### A tropical storm watch means that tropical storm conditions (sustained winds near 65 km/h or more) are possible over parts of the region within 36 hours. By nature, a tropical storm also implies the threat of local flooding from heavy rainfall - consult your local area forecast for possible rainfall warnings. Please continue to monitor alerts issued by the Canadian Hurricane Centre and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. Reports of storm conditions and impacts can be emailed directly to NSstorm@canada.ca or by tweeting reports by province using #NSStorm, #NBStorm, #PEStorm, #NLwx, #QCStorm or #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Large waves, pounding surf and elevated sea water levels are expected, possibly exceeding high astronomical tide. Wave heights: generally 6 to 8 metres with higher waves possible, breaking upon approach to shore. Locations: Burin and Connaigre Peninsulas. Time span: continuing until this evening. Remarks: Long-period swells and very large waves are expected to build along the south coast as Post-Tropical Storm Teddy tracks towards the island. These waves may coincide with high tide to produce elevated water levels, with potential for local flooding and coastal erosion, especially along south-facing shorelines. Damage to coastal infrastructure may occur. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant rainfall associated with the remnants of Post-Tropical Storm Teddy continues. Total rainfall: 30 to 45 mm with locally higher amounts possible. Time span: until Thursday morning. Locations: southeastern Labrador. Remarks: Rain has tapered to drizzle near the Strait, and will ease over areas from Lodge Bay northward this afternoon. The rain will redevelop over all locations this evening, however, and then end across the region on Thursday morning. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A series of vigorous frontal systems will move across the south coast of BC today through Saturday. They will bring periods of heavy rain and strong winds in the first active storm cycle of the the fall season. The first system will spread rain to Vancouver Island and the mainland today and Thursday. Rainfall intensity will vary through the day and across regions. Over Vancouver Island, total rainfall amounts over the two day period will generally range from 15 to 40 mm, with amounts in excess of 100 mm over West Vancouver Island. For the mainland coast, total rainfall amounts will range from 30 mm to over 50 mm for the two day period. The heaviest rainfall amounts are currently expected near the mountains. This system will also bring strong southeast winds to the west coast of Vancouver Island early this morning. Strong winds over the Strait of Georgia and surrounding regions will peak early this morning. Winds will diminish later today, but gusty conditions will continue. Tonight and Thursday, unsettled conditions will bring a risk of thunderstorms across the region as well. The combination of heavy rain with leaves on the ground may lead to localized flooding. Strong winds may also lead to power outages. The wet pattern will continue with more rain expected Friday and Saturday. Rainfall and wind warnings are now in effect for some regions, and will be updated as needed. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-09-24T03:06:18-00:00

properties.Title: Tropical Cyclone Information Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: For Post-tropical Storm Teddy. The next full statement will be issued by 3:00 P.M. ADT. Post-tropical storm Teddy made landfall in eastern Nova Scotia this morning and will continue to move northeastward as it weakens. 1. Summary of basic information at 12:00 P.M. ADT. Location: 46.3 north 61.6 west. About 15 kilometers northwest of Port Hood. Maximum sustained winds: 100 kilometers per hour. Present movement: northeast at 35 kilometers per hour. Minimum estimated central pressure: 970 millibars. 2. Summary of latest information. Based on satellite presentation, radar and recent observations along coastal Nova Scotia, post-tropical storm Teddy made landfall close to 10 AM this morning near or just east of Sheet Harbour. Confirmation from a private weather station and one of our own suggests Teddy's pressure was around 965 mb. The pressure will continue to rise in the coming hours. Very strong south to southeasterlies have been observed just to the east of the center. Hart Island reported a peak wind of 108 km/h and a gust to 104 km/h in Eskasoni, on Cape Breton Island. Forecaster(s): Mercer/March ### Please continue to monitor alerts issued by the Canadian Hurricane Centre and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
Expires: 2020-09-24T04:59:08-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-09-23T14:25:08-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2456150579.2020

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Tropical Cyclone Information Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: For Post-tropical Storm Teddy. The next intermediate information statement will be issued by 12:00 P.M. ADT, followed by the next full information statement at 3:00 P.M. Post-Tropical Storm Teddy continues to bring heavy rain, strong winds and heavy pounding surf to eastern Nova Scotia and southern Newfoundland today. The centre of Teddy is expected to make landfall along the Eastern Shore of Nova Scotia in the next hour or so. 1. Summary of basic information at 9:00 A.M. ADT. Location: near 44.9 North 62.4 West. About 91 kilometres east-northeast of Halifax. Maximum sustained winds: 110 kilometres per hour. Present movement: northeast at 37 kilometres per hour. Minimum central pressure: 960 millibars. Teddy remains a powerful post-tropical storm on its approach towards eastern Nova Scotia this morning. It will continue to weaken as it travels across eastern Nova Scotia and into the southeastern Gulf of St. Lawrence this afternoon. The storm will then continue to weaken further as it moves across the eastern Gulf of St. Lawrence later this afternoon and towards northern Newfoundland tonight. 2. Public impacts and warnings summary: a. Wind. Wind and Tropical Storm warnings are in effect for the Atlantic coastline of Nova Scotia from Halifax to Cape Breton, where wind gusts of 80 to 110 km/h are occurring or expected into this afternoon. A Tropical Storm warning is in effect for the southwest coast of Newfoundland with wind gusts of 80 to 100 km/h possible into this afternoon. Tropical storm watches remain in effect for northern Nova Scotia, as well as Prince Edward Island and Iles de la Madeleine where winds gusting 70 to 80 possibly reaching 90 km/h are possible this afternoon. Given trees are still in full leaf, these winds could cause limbs to break with some tree falls, likely leading to many power outages. A Wreckhouse wind warning remains in effect for southwestern Newfoundland where winds could gust up to 130 km/h into this evening. b. Rainfall. Rainfall warnings are in effect for all of Nova Scotia except westernmost regions. Rainfall warnings are also in effect for Prince Edward Island, Les Iles de la Madeleine and parts of the south coast of Newfoundland. Rain, at times heavy, will continue for these areas today as Teddy makes landfall and continues northeast toward Newfoundland. Rainfall amounts generally of 50 to 80 mm have already fallen since yesterday, with the exception of Victoria county in Cape Breton where 100 to 130 mm have fallen. With additional rainfall today, the total rainfall expected remains at 50 to 100 mm, with upwards of 150 mm possible for Victoria county. c. Surge/Waves. Storm surge warnings are in effect along the Atlantic coast of Nova Scotia from Halifax - East of Porters Lake through to eastern Cape Breton County, as well as the southwestern coast of Newfoundland. Large swells will continue to effect the Atlantic coast this morning with waves of up to 8 to 10 metres possible, and will break higher along parts of the coast. Elevated water levels and large waves are occurring along eastern parts of the Atlantic coast of Nova Scotia this morning and will continue to develop over southwestern Newfoundland into this afternoon. There is also a chance for Prince Edward Island and Iles de la Madeleine today when winds increase out of the northwest behind the system. The highest risk is the combination of the very large waves combining with the storm surge to cause dangerous conditions along the Atlantic coasts of Nova Scotia and Newfoundland. Rough and pounding surf, localised flooding and coastal infrastructure damage and erosion are likely in vulnerable areas, even outside of the times of high tide. 3. Marine impacts and warning summary: Storm warnings remain for most waters south of Nova Scotia. Gale warnings are in effect for most Gulf of St. Lawrence waters as well as the southwestern Grand Banks. Teddy will continue to produce waves of 8 to 10 metres east of the storms track into through Fourchu and possibly reaching the southwest coast of Newfoundland. In addition, High Water Level warnings continue to be in effect for Eastern Shore, Fourchu and the Southwest Coast. Both marine buoys B44150 and B44137 saw significant wave heights of 11 metres with B44137 reaching a peak wave height of 25 metres in the overnight period. Forecaster(s): McArthur/Mercer/March ### Please continue to monitor alerts issued by the Canadian Hurricane Centre and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
Expires: 2020-09-24T04:59:55-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-09-23T11:37:55-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2911336877.2020

properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. Strong southeasterly winds of 50-70 km/h continue along the Sunshine Coast through mid this afternoon. Thereafter, winds will diminish below warning criteria but remain gusty into this evening. ### High winds may toss loose objects or cause tree branches to break. Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, at times heavy, is expected. Heavy rainfall will continue over Howe Sound and Metro Vancouver today, and will spread to the Fraser Valley tonight. This moisture-laden system will deliver 40-70 mm of rain by Thursday morning. Rainfall rates will lessen on Thursday but persistent moist, onshore flow will cause showers, heavy at times, to continue Thursday. The heaviest rain amounts are expected near the mountains and eastern sections of the Fraser Valley. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Rainfall warnings are issued when significant rainfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.

properties.Title: Tropical Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Tropical storm force winds of 70 gusting to 100 km/h over exposed areas from Post-tropical Storm Teddy can be expected over the above regions. Tropical storm force winds associated with Post-Tropical Storm Teddy will continue to affect eastern Nova Scotia for another couple hours, accompanied by rain at times heavy. Potential wind gusts: 80 to 90 km/h possibly reaching 110 km/h over exposed areas along the Eastern Shore and parts of Cape Breton.. Locations: Coastal regions of eastern mainland Nova Scotia and Cape Breton. Time span: continuing until early the afternoon. Remarks: Tropical storm force southeasterly winds are expected or occurring over the eastern mainland of Nova Scotia and over portions of Cape Breton. Winds will ease early this afternoon. ### These winds could break tree branches potentially resulting in downed utility lines. A tropical storm warning means that tropical storm conditions (sustained winds near 65 km/h or more) are expected over parts of the region within 24 hours. By nature, a tropical storm also implies the threat of local flooding from heavy rainfall - consult your local area forecast for possible rainfall warnings. Please continue to monitor alerts issued by the Canadian Hurricane Centre and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. Reports of storm conditions and impacts can be emailed directly to NSstorm@canada.ca or by tweeting reports by province using #NSStorm, #NBStorm, #PEStorm, #NLwx, #QCStorm or #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Fog Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Near zero visibility in fog is expected or occurring. An area of dense fog is expected to persist until this afternoon. ### Visibility may be significantly and suddenly reduced to near zero. Fog advisories are issued when near zero visibilities in fog are expected or occurring. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NTStorm.
Expires: 2020-09-23T22:59:02-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-09-23T18:05:02-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1402468922.2020
Area: Aklavik Region, Inuvik Region
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Tropical Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Tropical storm force winds of 70 gusting to 100 km/h over exposed areas from Post-tropical Storm Teddy can be expected over the above regions. Tropical storm force winds ahead of now Post-Tropical Storm Teddy will continue to affect these regions today. Potential wind gusts: Between 90 to 110 km/h this afternoon. Locations: Southwestern coastal Newfoundland from Burgeo - Ramea west to Ports aux Basques. Time span: this afternoon then easing tonight. Remarks: Strong easterly winds will continue across these areas ahead of Post-Tropical Storm Teddy approaching from the south. A second round of strong southeasterly winds will develop this afternoon as Teddy passes to the west. These winds will diminish late in the evening. ### These winds could break tree branches potentially resulting in downed utility lines. A tropical storm warning means that tropical storm conditions (sustained winds near 65 km/h or more) are expected over parts of the region within 24 hours. By nature, a tropical storm also implies the threat of local flooding from heavy rainfall - consult your local area forecast for possible rainfall warnings. Please continue to monitor alerts issued by the Canadian Hurricane Centre and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. Reports of storm conditions and impacts can be emailed directly to NSstorm@canada.ca or by tweeting reports by province using #NSStorm, #NBStorm, #PEStorm, #NLwx, #QCStorm or #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-09-24T15:29:09-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-09-23T09:30:09-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1533616723.2020
Area: Burgeo - Ramea, Channel-Port aux Basques and vicinity
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: High Water Level Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Higher than normal water levels are expected or occurring. Locations: south facing shorelines from Port aux Basques to Ramea. Maximum wave heights: 7 to 9 metres, breaking upon approach to shore. Time span: continuing until this evening, with the most severe conditions expected this afternoon. High tide: 1 P.M. to 6 P.M. today. Remarks: Large waves and pounding surf can cause damage to coastal infrastructure, especially at locations that have been prone to impacts during similar events in the past. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. For more information monitor Canadian Coast Guard radio or Weatheradio stations.
Expires: 2020-09-24T04:29:10-00:00

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, at times heavy, is expected. Heavy rainfall is forecast for Howe Sound and the North Shore as a vigorous frontal system arrives on the coast today. Rainfall amounts of 40-70 mm are forecast by Thursday morning. Strong southerly winds of will accompany the frontal system. Through Howe Sound winds will rise to 40 to 60 km/h this morning and will gradually ease by this evening. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Rainfall warnings are issued when significant rainfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-09-24T02:40:18-00:00

properties.Title: Tropical Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Tropical storm force winds of 70 gusting to 100 km/h over exposed areas from Post-tropical Storm Teddy can be expected over the above regions. Tropical storm force winds associated with Post-Tropical Storm Teddy will continue to affect Nova Scotia this morning, accompanied by rain at times heavy. Potential wind gusts: 80 to 90 km/h possibly reaching 110 km/h over exposed areas along the Eastern Shore and parts of Cape Breton.. Locations: Coastal regions of eastern mainland Nova Scotia and Cape Breton. Time span: continuing until the afternoon. Remarks: Tropical storm force southeasterly winds are expected or occurring over the eastern mainland of Nova Scotia and over portions of Cape Breton. Winds will ease this afternoon. ### These winds could break tree branches potentially resulting in downed utility lines. A tropical storm warning means that tropical storm conditions (sustained winds near 65 km/h or more) are expected over parts of the region within 24 hours. By nature, a tropical storm also implies the threat of local flooding from heavy rainfall - consult your local area forecast for possible rainfall warnings. Please continue to monitor alerts issued by the Canadian Hurricane Centre and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. Reports of storm conditions and impacts can be emailed directly to NSstorm@canada.ca or by tweeting reports by province using #NSStorm, #NBStorm, #PEStorm, #NLwx, #QCStorm or #ONStorm.
